Acanthostega: one of the first animals with limbs! It had a flat, shovel-like head and could move on land, but it still spent most of its time in the water
Acrocanthosaurus: a massive hunter with a sail-like structure on its back
Aepyornis: the "elephant bird". This flightless bird was a giant, with a towering height and weighing over 1,000 pounds
Alamosaurus: a giant sauropod. It was one of the very last sauropods to exist before the dinosaurs went extinct
Albertosaurus: unlike its bulkier cousin, the T-Rex, Albertosaurus was relatively slender and had long, powerful hind legs. Scientists think it was an excellent runner, capable of chasing down prey
Alioramus: a medium-sized tyrannosaur, with a long snout and small horns
Allosaurus: a very large hunter. It was a dominant predator of its time
Alphadon: a small, opossum-like mammal that lived alongside dinosaurs
Amphicoelias: a huge, plant-eating sauropod dinosaur with a very long neck, like a cousin to Diplodocus. It lived in North America
Anchisaurus: a medium-sized dino. Scientists first thought it ate meat, but now we know it was a plant-eater
Ankylosaurus: the "armored tank" of the dinosaur world! This plant-eater was covered head-to-toe in thick, bony plates and had a giant, bony club on its tail for defense
Anurognathus: a very small pterosaur with a wingspan of only 1 foot. It had a very short tail and probably caught insects in mid-air
Apatosaurus: the Dinosaur with a Secret Identity! Say hello to one of the biggest animals to ever walk the Earth! The plant-eating Apatosaurus was a truly massive dinosaur. Its name, which means Deceptive Lizard, is one of the coolest in science because it tells an amazing story. Over a century ago, during the famous Bone Wars of the late 1800s, two famous fossil hunters thought they had discovered two different dinosaurs: Apatosaurus and Brontosaurus. They were both huge, long-necked beasts! Soon, scientists decided these two names belonged to just one dino. Apatosaurus was the official winner, and Brontosaurus vanished! But hold on—the mystery isn't over! In a thrilling modern twist, new research has convinced many paleontologists that Brontosaurus was a real, unique dinosaur all along! It’s a scientific comeback story! This long-running debate is proof that even in science, there are still exciting legends waiting to be revived
Araeoscelis: a small, lizard-like reptile with a long tail and slender limbs
Arandaspis: one of the earliest to have a head shield made of bony plates
Archaeopteryx: the earliest known bird. It was a small, bird-like dinosaur with feathers, but it also had teeth and claws on its wings, which shows the link between birds and dinosaurs
Archaeothyris: a very early pelycosaur. It was a small, lizard-like reptile and one of the earliest known mammal-like reptiles
Archelon: a gigantic sea turtle, and the largest turtle ever found! It had a broad shell and huge flippers for swimming
Arctops: arctops was a little bigger than a large dog. It walked on four strong legs
Ardeosaurus: a small, lizard-like reptile, a type of gecko, with a slender body and a long tail
Argentavis: one of the largest flying birds ever. It had a gigantic wingspan of up to 23 feet!
Argentinosaurus: one of the largest animals to ever walk the Earth! This plant-eater, found in Argentina, was a type of sauropod and could grow to be longer than three school buses
Askeptosaurus: a long, slender marine reptile with a long neck and tail. It was an excellent swimmer and had a very narrow, pointed snout full of sharp teeth for catching fish
Aspidorhynchus: a fish with a long, slender body and a long, pointed snout
Bactrosaurus: an early type of "duck-billed" dinosaur (Hadrosaur). It was a plant-eater that was smaller than its later cousins and had a long, strong spine
Baryonyx: an unusual, fish-eating dinosaur It had a long snout and a huge thumb claw
Bernissartia: a small, slender crocodile, one of the smallest crocs ever found!
Boreaspis: with its narrow head shield and a snout that curved down, this fish was great at sweeping through mud
Bothriolepis: a small, armored fish with a flat, shovel-like head shield
Brachiosaurus: this enormous dino had a giraffe-like posture because its front legs were longer than its back legs
Cacops: a small amphibian with heavily armored skin
Camarasaurus: a common sauropod. It had a short, boxy head and a shorter, thicker neck compared to its relatives
Camptosaurus: a small to medium-sized, quick plant-eating dinosaur that could walk on two legs or four. It's an ancestor to later big plant-eaters like Iguanodon
Canobius: a small fish with a long body and covered in thick, bony scales
Carcharodontosaurus: a massive hunter with large, shark-like teeth
Casea: a plant-eating reptile, with a broad, flat body and a small head
Cearadactylus: a large pterosaur with a wingspan of 11 feet. It was likely a fish-eater with a hook-like structure on its upper jaw
Centrosaurus: a plant-eating dinosaur that lived about 75 million years ago. It was a cousin of the more famous Triceratops, but had its own very cool look!
Cephalaspis: had a broad, horseshoe-shaped head shield that protected its eyes and gills
Ceratodus: a type of ancient lungfish with large, unique tooth plates that looked a bit like horns. This fish could be found in fresh water all over the world
Ceratosaurus: a large carnivore, recognized by the horn on its nose and bony crests over its eyes
Ceresiosaurus: a large swimming reptile with a very long neck and a long, flat tail, perfect for steering and swimming fast in the Triassic oceans
Cetiosaurus: a large, long-necked herbivorous sauropod, one of the first to be discovered
Champsosaurus: a large, crocodile-like aquatic reptile with a long snout and tail
Chasmatosaurus: when we first discovered Chasmatosaurus it was called Proterosuchus. This is an example of Junior and Senior Synomyms with taxonomy. a large, heavily built predator
Chasmosaurus: a horned dinosaur like Triceratops, but its large neck frill had two huge, 'opening-like' holes. Its name means "opening lizard."
Cladoselache: one of the earliest known sharks. It was streamlined and had two dorsal fins and a symmetrical tail
Claudiosaurus: a very early member of this group
Climatius: a spiny shark that was a small, slender fish with rows of spines along its sides for protection
Coccosteus: a small, armored fish with a broad, flat head shield
Coelophysis: a medium-sized, agile dino. It had grasping claws on its hands
Coelurosauravus: this reptile had a membrane of skin supported by long bones, allowing it to glide from tree to tree!
Coelurus: a small, agile dino. It was very similar to Coelophysis and had strong, clawed fingers
Compsognathus: tiny!. It was once thought to be the smallest dinosaur ever discovered!
Corythosaurus: a duck-billed dinosaur with a tall, helmet-like crest on its head
Cotylorhynchus: a large, heavy-bodied plant-eater with a barrel-shaped body
Crassigyrinus: a large, long-bodied amphibian with a huge mouth and tiny limbs
Crusafontia: a small, squirrel-like mammal, likely an insectivore
Cryptocleidus: a medium-sized plesiosaur. It had a long neck, small head, and large flippers
Ctenurella: a small, armored fish with a broad, flat head shield
Cyclurus: an extinct type of freshwater ray-finned fish, closely related to the modern bowfin. It had a rounded tail and was a common sight in ancient lakes and rivers
Cymbospondylus: a very large ichthyosaur, . It had a long, eel-like slender body and a long tail
Cynognathus: a medium-sized, dog-like reptile. It had a powerful jaw and was a top predator
Dapedium: a small fish with a deep, flat body
Dartmuthia: had a head shield with a prominent spine and two large spikes on its sides
Daspletosaurus: a large tyrannosaurid, a fearsome predator closely related to T-Rex
Deinonychus: a fast, agile raptor with a distinctive, sickle-shaped claw on each foot
Deinosuchus: a gigantic crocodile, one of the largest crocodiles ever to live, with jaws powerful enough to crush large dinosaurs
Deltoptychius: a chimera with a deep, shovel-like head and large fins
Desmatosuchus: a large, heavily armored reptile with long spikes on its shoulders
Diatryma: a huge, flightless bird. it had a massive head and a huge, powerful beak
Dicraeosaurus: a medium-sized sauropod. It had a shorter neck and a unique forked spine on its neck vertebrae
Dicynodon: a common plant-eater, known for its toothless beak and tusks
Dilophosaurus: a large hunter famous for the two crests on its head
Dimetrodon: a famous meat-eater. It was a top predator known for its large, prominent sail
Dimorphodon: a medium-sized pterosaur with a wingspan of 4 feet. It had a big head with two different types of teeth
Dinichthys: a large placoderm, similar to Dunkleosteus but smaller
Dinornis: the moa, the tallest known bird
Diplocaulus: famous for its unique boomerang-shaped head
Diplodocus: a very long sauropod, stretching up to 85 feet! It had an extremely long neck and a thin, whip-like tail it could use for defense
Dipnorhynchus: this 3-foot-long predator had a special, box-like skull fused together like the animals that eventually walked on land, which helped it crush the hard shells of its prey!
Dipterus: a small lungfish with a long body and a large dorsal fin
Dodo: the famous flightless bird, unfortunately driven to extinction in the 17th century
Doryaspis: this fish had a broad, spiky head shield and a long spine on its back. Shaped like a hydrofoil
Drepanaspis: one of the first ray-like fish! It had a broad, flat, horseshoe-shaped head shield that covered its eyes
Dromaeosaurus: a small, bird-like theropod, known for its powerful jaws and sharp claws
Dromiceiomimus: built for speed, with long legs and a long neck, just like an ostrich
Dryosaurus: a lightweight, fast-running, two-legged plant-eating dinosaur. Its strong legs and stiff tail helped it run away quickly from predators in the Jurassic forests
Dsungaripterus: a large pterosaur with a wingspan of 10 feet. It had a bony crest on its head and an upward-curving jaw, which may have been used for cracking open shellfish
Dunkleosteus: a gigantic placoderm with a massive head shield and powerful, scissor-like jaws made of bone
Echinodon: a tiny dino. It's special because its teeth looked like a mammal's teeth
Edaphosaurus: a large, plant-eating reptile. It had a prominent sail on its back
Edmontosaurus: also known as Anatosaurus, This Dino was a very large, common "duck-billed" dinosaur (Hadrosaur) that walked on two or four legs. Fossils of its skin show it didn't have a large crest, just a flat head
Efraasia: a smaller European dino. It probably spent most of its time walking on all fours but could stand up on two legs when it needed to
Elaphrosaurus: a slender, long-necked, and lightweight theropod, likely a fast runner and might have eaten eggs
Elasmosaurus: a huge plesiosaur! It had an extremely long neck, a small head, and large flippers
Elginia: a small, robust reptile, a bit like a miniature version of a pareiasaur
Eogyrinus: a very large amphibian with a long, snake-like body
Eryops: a huge, strong amphibian with a broad, flat head and powerful legs, making it a strong predator
Erythrosuchus: a giant 'ruling reptile' and one of the largest predators of its time
Eudimorphodon: a small pterosaur with a wingspan of about 2.5 feet. It was a fish-eater with a long tail and a mouth full of sharp teeth
Euhelopus: a large sauropod, with a long neck and a shorter tail
Euoplocephalus: another heavily armored dinosaur like Ankylosaurus, covered in bony plates, but it was famous for having armored eyelids and a big tail club
Euparkeria: a small, active predator that could run on two legs for short bursts
Eurhinosaurus: a medium-sized ichthyosaur, known for having a very long, sword-like snout
Eusthenopteron: scientists call it a 'fish with legs' because the bones in its fins were very similar to the limb bones of early land animals
Eustreptospondylus: a medium-sized hunter with a large head and powerful jaws
Gallimimus: the largest of the 'ostrich dinosaurs'. It was a very fast runner, just like the others
Gemuendina: a small, armored fish with a flat, shovel-like head shield
Gerrothorax: an aquatic amphibian with an extremely flattened head
Giganotosaurus: a massive hunter. It was one of the largest land predators ever
Gracilisuchus: a small, slender, and lightly-built archosaur, an early relative of crocodiles
Great Auk: a flightless, penguin-like bird. It used its small wings to swim underwater
Greererpeton: an aquatic amphibian with a long, snake-like body
Griphognathus: a lungfish known for its long, pointed snout
Groenlandaspis: a small, armored fish with a flat, shovel-like head shield
Gyroptychius: a small lungfish with a long, slender body
Hadrosaurus: a duck-billed dinosaur, one of the first dinosaurs found in North America
Haramiyia: one of the earliest known primitive mammals, It was a small, rodent-like mammal
Harpagornis: one of the largest eagles ever, with a wingspan of up to 10 feet and powerful talons for hunting
Helicoprion: a prehistoric shark-like fish famous for its bizarre lower jaw—a spiral-shaped "tooth whorl" that looked like a circular saw!
Hemicyclaspis: had a broad, horseshoe-shaped head shield that protected its eyes and gills
Henodus: a small, turtle-like reptile with a broad, flat shell and short legs
Hesperornis: a large, flightless diving bird. It had teeth and strong legs for swimming and hunting fish
Heterodontosaurus: a small dinosaur. It had tusks like a boar and different teeth for cutting and grinding plants
Homalcocephale: a medium-sized pachycephalosaur. Its skull was flat and thick, not dome-shaped
Hovasaurus: a small, lizard-like marine reptile with a long body and slender limbs, perfect for swimming
Hybodus: a successful shark with two dorsal fins and small spines
Hylaeosaurus: one of the first dinosaurs ever discovered! This armored, plant-eating dinosaur had large, long spikes sticking out from its shoulders
Hylonomus: a small, lizard-like reptile, one of the oldest known reptiles!
Hypacrosaurus: a duck-billed dinosaur with a tall, rounded crest on its head
Hyperodapedon: a medium-sized reptile with a strong, robust body and a short tail
Hypsilophodon: a small, agile plant-eating dinosaur known for its speed
Hypsognathus: a small, lizard-like reptile with a long tail and short legs
Ichthyornis: a seabird with strong wings for flying, and, like some early birds, it still had teeth!
Ichthyosaurus: one of the first ichthyosaurs ever discovered. Characterized best by its dolphin-like body and long tail
Ichthyostega: one of the first animals with limbs! It had a flat, shovel-like head and could move on land, but it still spent most of its time in the water
Iguanodon: a large plant-eater known for its distinctive thumb spikes
Ischnacanthus: a spiny shark, small and slender
Ischyodus: a small, long-bodied chimera with a long, pointed snout
Jamoytius: a small, eel-like creature without a backbone
Karaurus: an early salamander, one of the earliest known modern-type amphibians
Kentrosaurus: a smaller relative of Stegosaurus, this plant-eater was covered in bony plates and had long, sharp, defensive spikes all down its back and tail
Keraterpeton: had a long tail and two small horn-like bumps on its head
Kritosaurus: a duck-billed dinosaur with a unique crest that looked like a 'Roman nose'
Kronosaurus: a gigantic, short-necked plesiosaur. It had a huge head and powerful flippers
Kuehneosaurus: a small, gliding reptile that had broad, wing-like extensions on its ribs that allowed it to glide from tree to tree
Labidosaurus: a small, lizard-like reptile with a long tail and short legs
Lagosuchus: a small, early reptile so similar to dinosaurs that scientists think it could have been a direct ancestor
Lambeosaurus: a duck-billed dinosaur with a hollow, hatchet-like crest on its head
Lariosaurus: a small, lizard-like reptile with a long body and short limbs
Latimeria: a modern coelacanth, a 'living fossil' that has been around for 400 million years
Leptolepis: a small, bony fish, an ancestor to modern teleosts
Lesothosaurus: small!. It was one of the earliest plant-eating dinosaurs and had long legs for running away from predators
Limnofregata: a frigate-like bird, with long wings and a forked tail
Liopleurodon: a very large, short-necked plesiosaur. It had a massive head and powerful flippers
Longisquama: a small, strange reptile that lived before the dinosaurs. It had a row of very long, unusual, feather-like scales sticking up from its back
Lystrosaurus: a common plant-eater, found worldwide! It had a stout body and tusks and survived the biggest extinction event in Earth's history!
Macropoma: was a real-life cousin to the super-rare modern coelacanth, and looked a lot like a modern fish with a unique, three-part tail and stalked fins
Maiasaura: a duck-billed dinosaur famous for its nesting colonies, known as the 'good mother lizard'
Mamenchisaurus: this huge dinosaur was famous for having the longest neck of any known animal!
Massetognathus: a dog-sized cynodont, a mammal-like reptile that was likely herbivorous
Massospondylus: a great dino with a long neck and tail, and we've found so many fossils of it that we know a lot about how it lived
Megalania: a gigantic terrestrial lizard, and one of the largest land lizards ever!
Megalosaurus: a large hunter. It was the first dinosaur ever scientifically described!
Megazostrodon: a very early mammal. It was a tiny, shrew-like creature. It had a long tail and sharp teeth
Meiolania: a medium-sized turtle with a broad shell and a long tail that had spikes on it!
Mesosaurus: a small, aquatic reptile. Its discovery helped prove that these continents were once joined together!
Metriorhynchus: a large crocodile that had a long, narrow snout and a fish-like tail, allowing it to swim fast in the open ocean
Mixosaurus: a transitional ichthyosaur, showing features of both primitive and advanced forms
Mosasaurus: the first mosasaur ever found. It was a giant marine lizard and one of the most powerful marine predators of the Late Cretaceous
Moschops: a huge, plant-eating reptile. It had a thick, robust body and a small head
Moythomasia: a small fish with a long, slender body and a large dorsal fin on its back
Muraenosaurus: a long-necked plesiosaur, a marine reptile that likely hunted fish
Mussaurus: a small dinosaur. Its name means 'mouse lizard' because the first fossils found were tiny babies!
Neocathartes: a vulture-like bird with a hooked beak and long legs
Nodosaurus: an armored dinosaur that was heavily built with a short tail and stout legs
Nothosaurus: a strong swimmer with a long body and short limbs
Ophiacodon: a medium-sized, semi-aquatic reptile. It had a long, narrow head and strong jaws
Ophiderpeton: snake-like amphibians that were long and slender and had no limbs
Ophthalmosaurus: an ichthyosaur known for its extremely large eyes, adapted for deep-sea hunting
Opisthocoelicaudia: this 49-foot-long sauropod had a strong, stout tail that might have helped it stand up on two legs to reach high branches
Ornitholestes: a small, fast-running, two-legged meat-eater whose name means "bird robber," though it probably ate small reptiles and mammals too
Ornithomimus: an 'ostrich-like' dinosaur, a fast-running theropod with a toothless beak
Ornithosuchus: a large, crocodile-like reptile that could walk on two legs for short periods
Osteodontornis: a huge seabird. It had a wingspan of up to 16 feet and a unique beak with bony "pseudo-teeth" for grabbing fish
Osteolepis: a small fish covered in thick, bony scales and was a relative of the first land animals
Oviraptor: a small, bird-like dinosaur with a crest on its head. Its name means 'egg thief' but it actually protected its nest
Pachycephalosaurus: the 'thick-headed lizard'. It had a massive, very thick dome-shaped skull
Pachyrhachis: a small marine snake. It was one of the earliest known snakes to live in the ocean
Pachyrhinosaurus: a large horned dinosaur that had a thick, bumpy boss instead of a horn on its nose
Palaelodus: a flamingo-like bird. It had a short, slender neck and long legs for wading
Palaeobatrachus: an ancient frog, an early relative of modern frogs
Palaeoniscum: a small fish with a long, slender body
Palaeospondylus: a small, eel-like fish. It's a mystery to scientists because it had a long, slender body but no jaws or fins
Palaeotrionyx: a small turtle with a broad shell and a long tail
Panoplosaurus: an armored dinosaur that was heavily built with a short tail and stout legs
Pantylus: a small amphibian with a short tail and short legs
Paracyclotosaurus: a large amphibian with a very broad, flat head
Parasaurolophus: a duck-billed dinosaur with a huge, backward-pointing tube on its head, which may have been used for making loud calls
Pareiasaurus: a large, robust reptile that was heavily built with a short tail and stout legs
Peloneustes: a pliosaur, a short-necked marine reptile with a large head and powerful jaws
Peltobatrachus: a small, armored amphibian with bony plates on its back
Perleidus: a small fish with a long, slender body
Petrolacosaurus: one of the earliest known diapsids. It was a small, lizard-like reptile with a long tail and slender legs
Pharyngolepis: a small, jawless fish with a well-developed dorsal fin
Phorusrhacus: the "terror bird". It was a giant predator, with a massive beak and strong legs for running
Pisanosaurus: small, and is thought to be one of the most primitive members of the group of plant-eating dinosaurs
Pistosaurus: a small, lizard-like reptile that was a close relative of the nothosaurs
Placochelys: a small, turtle-like reptile with a broad, flat shell that looked like a turtle's
Placodus: one of the first placodonts, with strong, flat teeth for crushing shells
Planocephalosaurus: a small, lizard-like reptile. It was an early relative of the modern Tuatara and likely hunted insects
Platecarpus: a large marine lizard and powerful swimmer, a type of mosasaur
Plateosaurus: one of the first really big plant-eaters. It had a long neck and tail and strong back legs
Platyhystrix: an ancient, stocky amphibian (like a large salamander) that had a tall, flat, bony sail on its back, possibly to help it warm up or cool down
Platysomus: a small fish with a deep, flat body
Plesiosaurus: the first plesiosaur ever found! Its most distict features were its long neck, small head, and big flippers!
Pleurosaurus: a small, lizard-like marine reptile with a long body and slender limbs
Pliosaurus: a large, short-necked plesiosaur with a massive head and powerful jaws
Plotosaurus: another large mosasaur with a long body and tail, and was a fast swimmer
Polacanthus: an armored dinosaur with a large shield over its hips
Postosuchus: a large, heavily built predator that could walk on two legs
Prenocephale: a pachycephalosaur with a high, domed head, smaller than its famous relative
Pristichampsus: a large, robust crocodile that lived on land and had powerful jaws and hoof-like claws, suggesting it was a fast runner
Procompsognathus: a small, bipedal carnivorous theropod from the late Triassic period
Proganochelys: one of the earliest turtles, with a heavily armored shell
Prosaurolophus: a duck-billed dinosaur with a small, solid crest on its head
Proterosuchus: an early reptile, an ancestor to crocodiles and dinosaurs, that looked like a large lizard with a distinctive, strong, hooked snout for catching prey
Protorosaurus: a medium-sized reptile with a long, slender body and a long tail
Protostega: a giant sea turtle! One of the largest turtles ever
Protosuchus: a small, robust crocodile. It looked like a mix between a modern crocodile and a lizard
Pteranodon: a very large pterosaur with a wingspan of up to 24 feet. It had a long, bony crest on its head and a toothless beak, and it was a big fish-eater
Pteraspis: a typical pteraspids with a head shield covered in small bony plates
Pterodactylus: a small pterosaur with a wingspan of about 2.5 feet. It had a short tail and was one of the first pterosaurs ever discovered
Pterodaustro: a medium-sized pterosaur with a wingspan of over 7 feet. It had a beak filled with tons of bristle-like teeth, which it used to filter tiny creatures from the water, just like a flamingo!
Pteronisculus: a small fish with a long, slender body
Ptilodus: a small, squirrel-like mammal. It had a long tail and sharp teeth
Purgatorius: a small, shrew-like mammal. It is considered an early ancestor of primates
Pycnodus: a small fish with a deep, flat body and crushing teeth for eating hard-shelled prey
Quetzalcoatlus: a gigantic pterosaur with a wingspan of up to 39 feet. It was one of the largest flying animals ever to exist!
Rhamphorhynchus: a medium-sized pterosaur with a wingspan of 3 feet. Its long tail had a special diamond-shaped fin on the end. It also ate fish
Riojasaurus: a large dino. It had a heavy body and strong legs, which means it likely walked on all fours most of the time
Robertia: a small plant-eater, one of the earliest dicynodonts
Rutiodon: a large, crocodile-like reptile. It was a fish-eater with a long, slender snout
Saichania: an armored dinosaur that was heavily built with a short tail and stout legs
Saltasaurus: a medium-sized sauropod. It's one of the most interesting sauropods because it was covered in bony plates, like a dinosaur with armor!
Sarcosuchus: a gigantic crocodile, one of the largest crocodiles ever to live
Saurichthys: a fish with a long, thin body and a long, pointed snout
Saurolophus: a duck-billed dinosaur with a solid, backward-pointing spike on its head
Sauropelta: an armored dinosaur that was heavily built with a short tail and stout legs
Saurornithoides: a medium-sized, intelligent hunter, with a large brain and eyes
Scapanorhynchus: a shark with a long, pointed snout like a goblin shark today
Scaphognathus: a small pterosaur with a wingspan of about 3 feet. It had a deep head and a short snout
Scutellosaurus: a tiny, 4-foot-long dino. It had a surprise—bony plates on its back, making it an early armored dinosaur
Scutosaurus: a large, robust reptile with a short tail and stout legs
Seymouria: so similar to reptiles that scientists once thought it was one!
Shantungosaurus: the largest duck-billed dinosaur ever found
Shonisaurus: a giant ichthyosaur. It had a long, slender body and a long tail
Silvisaurus: an armored dinosaur that was heavily built with a short tail and stout legs
Sordes: a tiny pterosaur with a wingspan of only 1.5 feet. Fossils show it had a fuzzy covering, which might mean it was warm-blooded!
Spathobatis: a ray with a broad, flat body with a long tail and large fins
Sphenacodon: a meat-eating reptile with a deep, narrow skull and sharp teeth
Spinosaurus: an enormous hunter. It was possibly the largest carnivorous dinosaur ever and is famous for its massive sail
Stagonolepis: heavily armored and had a pig-like snout
Stegoceras: a small pachycephalosaur. It had a cool, dome-shaped skull
Stegosaurus: a large plant-eater famous for its huge plates and spiked tail
Stenonychosaurus: a medium-sized hunter. It had the largest brain for its body size of any dinosaur
Stenopterygius: a common ichthyosaur, with a dolphin-like body shape
Stethacanthus: famous for a weird, flat, anvil-shaped fin on its back
Strunius: was a tiny, stubby-bodied fish that swam during the late Devonian period. Despite its small size, it was a ferocious predator whose super-strong, hinged skull helped it bite and crush the armor of other small fish
Struthiosaurus: a small armored dinosaur that was heavily built with a short tail and stout legs
Stupendemys: a stupendously large turtle, about the size of a car!
Styracosaurus: a large horned dinosaur with a huge nose horn and a frill with long spikes around the edge
Supersaurus: a gigantic sauropod. It was one of the longest dinosaurs ever found
Talarurus: an armored dinosaur that was heavily built with a short tail and stout legs
Tanystropheus: a medium-sized reptile with a short body but an extremely long neck
Tarbosaurus: a very large tyrannosaur, very similar to T. rex
Teleosaurus: a large, marine crocodile with a long snout, perfect for snatching up fish
Temnodontosaurus: a medium-sized ichthyosaur. It had a long, slender body and a long tail
Tenontosaurus: a large, plant-eating dinosaur known for its very long tail
Teratosaurus: a very large, meat-eating reptile, but not a dinosaur! It belonged to a group called Rauisuchians and was one of the top predators of the Late Triassic period
Terrestrisuchus: a small, slender crocodile. It had long legs and a long tail for a life on the ground
Testudo: similar to modern tortoises. It had a broad shell and a short tail
Thadeosaurus: a small, lizard-like marine reptile also built for a life in the water
Thecodontosaurus: a tiny European dinosaur. It was one of the first dinosaurs ever discovered!
Thelodus: a small fish covered in tiny bony scales
Thescelosaurus: a small, plant-eating dinosaur with a long tail and short legs
Thrinaxodon: a small, carnivorous cynodont, an important transitional fossil showing mammal-like traits
Ticinosuchus: a large, quadrupedal archosaur, a crocodile-line predator
Titanosuchus: a large, carnivorous dinocephalian, a 'terrible crocodile
Torosaurus: a large horned dinosaur with the largest frill of any known land animal
Tremataspis: a small fish with a huge, flat, shovel-shaped head shield that covered most of its body
Triadobatrachus: considered the oldest and most primitive relative of modern frogs. It was small, had a frog-like head, long hind legs, but still had a short tail!
Triceratops: a large horned dinosaur with three horns on its face and a massive frill
Tristychius: a small, slender shark with a long tail and two dorsal fins
Tsintaosaurus: a duck-billed dinosaur with a long, rod-like crest that stuck straight up from its head
Tuojiangosaurus: a large plant-eater famous for its huge plates and spiked tail
Tyrannosaurus: the most famous giant! With a huge head, powerful jaws, and tiny two-fingered arms
Varanosaurus: an early pelycosaur, a synapsid with a long snout resembling a monitor lizard
Velociraptor: a small but fierce hunter, also with a large sickle claw
Vieraella: one of the earliest known frogs
Wuerhosaurus: a large plant-eater famous for its huge plates and spiked tail
Xenacanthus: an eel-like shark with a long dorsal fin and a spine on its head
Zalambdalestes: a small, shrew-like mammal. It had a long snout and sharp teeth
